SEARCH

Class Getopt

java.lang.Object
Getopt
public final class Getopt extends Object
A Java implementation of the C getopt() and getopt_long() functions for parsing command-line options. This class provides functionality similar to the GNU C getopt functions, allowing programs to parse command-line arguments according to Unix conventions.

This class is not thread-safe. Each thread should use its own Getopt instance.

Usage example for short options: 


 Getopt g = new Getopt(args, "ab:c");
 int c;
 while ((c = g.getOpt()) != -1) {
     switch (c) {
         case 'a': handleA(); break;
         case 'b': handleB(g.getOptArg()); break;
         case 'c': handleC(); break;
         case '?': handleError(); break;
     }
 }

Usage example for long options: 


 LongOption[] longopts = {
     new LongOption("help", false, null, 'h'),
     new LongOption("output", true, null, 'o')
 };
 Getopt g = new Getopt(args, "ho:", longopts);
 int c;
 while ((c = g.getOpt()) != -1) {
     switch (c) {
         case 'h': showHelp(); break;
         case 'o': setOutput(g.getOptArg()); break;
         case '?': handleError(); break;
     }
 }

  • Constructor Details

    • Getopt

      public Getopt(String[] args, String optstring)
      Constructs a new Getopt object for parsing command-line arguments with short options only.
      Parameters:
      args - The command-line arguments array to be parsed
      optstring - A string containing the legitimate option characters. A character followed by a colon (':') indicates that the option requires an argument. If the first character of optstring is ':', then getopt() returns ':' instead of '?' when a missing option argument is detected.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if args or optstring is null, or if optstring contains invalid option specifications

    • Getopt

      public Getopt(String[] args, String optstring, Getopt.LongOption[] longOptions)
      Constructs a new Getopt object for parsing both short and long options.
      Parameters:
      args - The command-line arguments array to be parsed
      optstring - A string containing the legitimate short option characters
      longOptions - Array of LongOption objects describing the valid long options
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if any parameter is null, or if optstring contains invalid option specifications

  • Method Details

    • getOpt

      public int getOpt()
      Parses the next command-line option. If this Getopt instance was constructed without long options and encounters an argument starting with "--", it will stop processing options at that point (treating it and all subsequent arguments as non-options).
      Returns:
      Returns an integer representing either: - The ASCII value of the short option character found - The val specified for a long option in the LongOption array - -1 when the argument list is exhausted or a non-option argument is found - '?' (ASCII 63) when an unknown option is found or an option is missing its argument - ':' (ASCII 58) when an option is missing its argument and optstring begins with ':'

    • getOptArg

      public String getOptArg()
      Returns the current option-argument if the last option required an argument.
      Returns:
      The argument value for the last processed option that required an argument, or null if the last option did not require an argument

    • getOptIndex

      public int getOptIndex()
      Returns the current index in the argument array. After getopt() has processed all options, this value indicates where the remaining non-option arguments begin in the args array.
      Returns:
      The index of the next element of the args array to be processed

    • setErrorReporting

      public void setErrorReporting(boolean enable)
      Controls whether error messages are printed to stderr.
      Parameters:
      enable - true to enable error reporting (default), false to disable

    • getErrorOpt

      public int getErrorOpt()
      Returns the ASCII value of the option character that caused the last error. When getOpt() returns '?' or ':', this value contains the ASCII value of the option character that caused the error.
      Returns:
      The ASCII value of the option character that caused the last error

    • getLongOptIndex

      public int getLongOptIndex()
      Returns the index of the matched long option in the long options array. Only meaningful after getOpt() has returned a long option value.
      Returns:
      The index in the long options array of the last matched long option, or -1 if the last option was a short option

    • hasOption

      public boolean hasOption(char option)
      Checks if a particular option was encountered during parsing.
      Parameters:
      option - the option character to check
      Returns:
      true if the option was found during parsing, false otherwise
